meanings.def: a building for people to live in, usually for one family
examples: in a house We live in a two-bedroom house.
in the house It was so hot outside we stayed in the house.
into the house He went into the house.
out of the house I had to get out of the house.
inside the house A light was on inside the house.
outside the house There was a police van parked outside the house.
at somebody's house Let's have a party at my house.
We need to build more houses in a way that respects the needs of the environment.
Investors were buying houses to rent them out.
What time do you leave the house in the morning (= to go to work)?
(British English) We're moving house (= leaving our house and going to live in a different one).
House prices (= prices of houses and flats) in London are still rising.
We went on a tour of the house and grounds (= for example, at a country house, open to the public).
They went from house to house, begging for food.
I finally tracked him down at his house in Denver.
I live in a group/​shared house.
It was easy to get lost in the rambling house.
It's stressful moving house.
Our challenge was to add onto the house in a respectful way.
Police officers have been searching the house for clues.
She shares a house with three other nurses.
The bank offers attractive rates to first-time house buyers.
The great house stood on the edge of the town.
The house faces south, making the most of the sun.
The house loomed over him as he waited at the front door.
The house stood a short distance from the wood.
Their house was repossessed when they couldn't keep up their mortgage payments.
They bought an old house and are gradually renovating it.
They built their own dream house overlooking the river.
They helped us with our house move.
They lived in a modest semi-detached house in the suburbs.
They've moved house and have invited us to their house-warming on Saturday.
We let out our house when we moved to America.
We're hoping to extend the house.
We're only planning on renting the house out for a few years.
We had to move out of our house.
a house occupied by students
houses overlooking the park
She went from house to house collecting signatures for her campaign.

meanings.def: all the people living in a house
examples: Be quiet or you'll wake the whole house!

meanings.def: a building used for a particular purpose, for example for holding meetings in or keeping animals or goods in
examples: an opera house
a henhouse

meanings.def: used in the names of office buildings
examples: Their offices are on the second floor of Chester House.

meanings.def: a company involved in a particular kind of business; an institution of a particular kind
examples: a fashion/banking/publishing house
a religious house (= a convent or a monastery)
The publishing house made its name by encouraging first-time writers.
She was a house model for Gucci (= a model employed by hte Gucci fashion house).

meanings.def: a restaurant
examples: a steakhouse
a coffee house
a bottle of house wine (= the cheapest wine available in a particular restaurant, sometimes not listed by name)

meanings.def: a group of people who meet to discuss and make the laws of a country
examples: Legislation requires approval by both houses of parliament.
The ‘Bundersrat’ is the upper house of the German parliament.
Elections to the lower house of parliament are by proportional representation.

meanings.def: the House of Commons or the House of Lords in the UK; the House of Representatives in the US
a group of people discussing something in a formal debate
examples: I urge the house to vote against the motion.

meanings.def: the part of a theatre where the audience sits; the audience at a particular performance
examples: playing to a full/packed/empty house (= to a large/small audience)
The spotlight faded and the house lights came up.

meanings.def: (in some British schools) an organized group of students of different ages who compete against other groups in sports competitions, etc. and who may, in boarding schools, live together in one building
an old and famous family
examples: the House of Windsor (= the British royal family)

meanings.def: a type of electronic dance music with a fast beat
to make everyone laugh or cheer, especially at a performance in the theatre
to remove people or things that are not necessary or wanted
examples: The new manager said he wanted to clean house.

meanings.def: to make your house clean
to eat a lot of somebody else’s food
examples: How much longer is he staying? He’s eating us out of house and home.

meanings.def: to become friends quickly and have a very friendly relationship
to do something or ask a question in a very complicated way instead of in a simple, direct way
examples: You did go all round the houses didn’t you? Why not get straight to the point?

meanings.def: to cook, clean and do all the other jobs around the house
examples: She kept house for her elderly parents.

meanings.def: used to say that everyone was very emotional about something
examples: There wasn't a dry eye in the house when they announced their engagement.

meanings.def: drinks or meals that are on the house are provided free by the pub or restaurant and you do not have to pay
examples: Have a drink on the house.

meanings.def: you should not criticize other people, because they will easily find ways of criticizing you
to play at being a family in its home
examples: The children were playing house, giving dinner to their dolls.

meanings.def: to organize your own business or improve your own behaviour before you try to criticize somebody else
very safe
to make a place your home
examples: They set up house together in a small flat in Brighton.
They want to set up house together.

idioms.def: to make everyone laugh or cheer, especially at a performance in the theatre
to remove people or things that are not necessary or wanted
examples: The new manager said he wanted to clean house.

idioms.idiom: eat somebody out of house and home
idioms.def: to eat a lot of somebody else’s food
examples: How much longer is he staying? He’s eating us out of house and home.

idioms.idiom: get on like a house on fire
idioms.def: to become friends quickly and have a very friendly relationship
to do something or ask a question in a very complicated way instead of in a simple, direct way
examples: You did go all round the houses didn’t you? Why not get straight to the point?

idioms.def: to cook, clean and do all the other jobs around the house
examples: She kept house for her elderly parents.

idioms.idiom: not a dry eye in the house
idioms.def: used to say that everyone was very emotional about something
examples: There wasn't a dry eye in the house when they announced their engagement.

idioms.def: drinks or meals that are on the house are provided free by the pub or restaurant and you do not have to pay
examples: Have a drink on the house.

idioms.idiom: people (who live) in glass houses shouldn’t throw stones
idioms.def: you should not criticize other people, because they will easily find ways of criticizing you
to play at being a family in its home
examples: The children were playing house, giving dinner to their dolls.

idioms.def: to organize your own business or improve your own behaviour before you try to criticize somebody else
to make a place your home
examples: They set up house together in a small flat in Brighton.
They want to set up house together.

meanings.def: to provide a place for a person or an animal to live
examples: The government is committed to housing the refugees.
He can barely afford to feed, clothe and house his family.
People whose homes were flooded were temporarily housed in community centres.
The prison normally houses about 200 medium-security prisoners.
At no time in the 19th century were the working classes adequately housed.
The losers in this society are the homeless and badly housed.
The fish can be temporarily housed in a smaller aquarium.
The rabbits were housed individually.

meanings.def: to be the place where something is kept or where something operates from
examples: The library houses a collection of 15 000 books.
The gallery houses 2 000 works of modern art.
The building also houses the offices of the District Medical Officer.
be housed in something The museum is housed in the Old Court House.
be housed at something Most film material housed at the Irish Film Archive is in English.
The new offices will house 600 administration staff.
The books were housed in glass-fronted cases.
These offices also house a printing firm.
